div.l: Vnto a Compere of his owne sorte
That lovid dice Riot and disporte
And hadde a wif that hilde for countenaunce
A Shoppe and swyvid for hure sustenaunce
Finitᵘur fabula Coci
Incipit prologus legis periti
Oure hoste sawe well that the bright sonne
The arke of his artificiall day had ronne
The iiijth parte and half an houre and more
And though he were not depe stirt in lore
He wist well it was the xxviij day
Of Aprill that is Messanger to May
And sawe well thethat thethat the shadowe of eủery tree
Was as in leyngth the same quantitee
That was the body erecte that caused it
And therfore by the shadowe he toke his wit
That phebus which that shone so clere and bright
Degrees was xlv clombe on hight
And for that day as in that latitude
Hit was xen at the Clocke he gan conclude
And sodenly he plyght his hors a boute
Lordynges quod he y warne you all the route
The iiijth parte of this day is gon
Nowe for the love of god and Seynt Iohn
Leseth no tyme as ferfurth as ye may
Lordynges the tyme wasteth bothe nyght and day
And stelith fro vs what prively slepyng
And what thrugh negligence in oure wakyng
As doith the streme that turneth neủere ageyne
Descendyng fro the Mounteyn into the pleyne
Well can Senek and many a Philosophre
Bywaile tyme mor than golde in Cofre
For loste of Catell may recoủered be
But lost of tyme shendith vs qd he
Woll it not com ageyn withoute drede
Nomore than will Malkyns Maydenhede
Whan she hath lost it in here wantonnesse
Lette vs not mowlen this in Idelnesse
